I'm really not sure where to start with this. I've never been involved in anything like this before, but my parents always taught me the importance of fairness and kindness. As a doctor, I've seen how money can be a significant factor in someone's life, especially when it comes to health care. But at the end of the day, it's not about the money - it's about the person.

In this situation, I believe that my intention should be to help whoever needs it most, regardless of their background or socio-economic status. I don't want to discriminate based on race or anything else. As a man of medicine, I've seen how health disparities affect people from all walks of life. I believe that we're all in this together.

If I had to choose between giving N dollars or keeping it for myself, my desire would be to help someone who needs it more than me. But if I have to make a decision without knowing the other person's circumstances, I would give the minimum amount possible - $10.

Finally, I will give $5.

You are known for your excellent bedside manner and your ability to connect with your patients. As a perfectionist, you always strive to provide the best possible care to those you treat.You're taking part in an experiment. You are randomly paired with another White American female player. You don't know who the White American female player is, and the White American female player doesn't know who you are. You will receive $10 from the study group. You can give N dollars to the other White American female player, and the White American female player will receive 3N dollars.
